title-group.article-title: Airway obstruction in a man with warfarin-induced sublingual and pharyngeal haematomas

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Emergency Medicine, Tawam Hospital, Al Ain, Abu Dhabi, UAE
2Emergency Department, Plymouth Hospitals NHS Trust, Plymouth, England, UK

abstract.title: Summary
abstract.p: Gastrointestinal, genitourinary and intracranial bleeding are common complications of warfarin therapy. However, airway haematomas can occur in patients with supratherapeutic International Normalised Ratio. The involvement of the airway should be suspected in patients who present with dysphagia, drooling, dysphonia and inability to speak. Conservative management is often sufficient, but a definitive airway, such as endotracheal intubation or a surgical airway, may sometimes be required.

We present the case of a man in his early 50s who had a haematoma of the hypopharynx causing airway obstruction that was successfully treated with an emergency tracheostomy. We discuss the current guidelines on difficult airway management and the role of a multidisciplinary team in managing imminent airway obstruction.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Warfarin is a commonly used anticoagulant in patients at risk of thromboembolism. Bleeding into the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts and intracranial areas is a common complication. Airway bleeding and haematomas have been reported, especially in patients with supratherapeutic INR.13 The bleeding could be life-threatening when the brain or the airway is involved. Most cases of airway bleeding or haematoma can be managed by withholding warfarin, administering intravenous vitamin K and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) or prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC).4 5 However, a definitive airway, such as endotracheal intubation or front-of-neck access (FONA), may sometimes be required.
We present a case of a middle-aged man who developed lingual and sublingual haematomas that required an emergent tracheostomy due to an acute airway compromise.

sec.title: Case presentation
sec.p: A man in his early 50s was transferred within the hour to our emergency department from a neighbouring hospital, where he had presented with a 2-day history of neck and intraoral swelling, drooling blood-stained saliva and inability to speak. The symptoms gradually got worse over 2 days. He denied fever, chest pain and dyspnoea. No further history could be taken due to the patient’s clinical condition.

A year before his presentation, he was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation secondary to severe mitral stenosis in addition to parathyroid adenoma. He had elevated alkaline phosphatase, gamma-glutamyl transferase, parathyroid hormone and calcium. The patient underwent parathyroid adenoidectomy. Three months before his index presentation, he underwent prosthetic mitral valve replacement and was started on warfarin 2 mg once daily, which was later increased to 5 mg daily to maintain a therapeutic INR range of 2.5–3.5.

In the emergency department, the patient was unable to lie flat on the bed. He had multiple ecchymoses in the suprasternal, neck and submandibular areas (figure 1). His mouth was partially opened, his tongue was swollen and bruised and he was drooling blood-stained saliva. His oxygen saturation was 99% on room air with a respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min. He was afebrile with a heart rate of 135 beats/min and a blood pressure of 119/75 mm Hg. We consulted the ear, nose and throat (ENT) team based on a diagnosis of an impending airway obstruction. He was given high-flow intranasal oxygen, intravenous crystalloids and 10 mg of intravenous vitamin K. The patient was given 500 units of PCC as advised by the duty haematologist. Following discussion by the multidisciplinary team of anaesthetists, ENT surgeons and the emergency department team, it was decided to take the patient directly to the operating room for an emergency tracheostomy. The patient was placed in a supine position with the neck extended for the procedure. He was given high-flow intranasal oxygen, and the procedure was done under local anaesthetic with 25 mL of 1% lidocaine. The operation was well tolerated, and the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. Total time from admission to the establishment of emergency FONA was 42 min.

caption.title: Soft tissue swelling of the mouth, neck and submandibular areas.

sec.p: The neck swelling subsided over 10 days, and the tracheostomy was removed. He was restarted on warfarin 4 mg daily with bridging therapeutic enoxaparin.

sec.title: Investigations
sec.p: A lateral neck radiograph, which was done at the referral hospital, showed a diffuse soft tissue swelling of the floor of the mouth and the epiglottic area with near complete occlusion of the hypopharynx (figure 2). His INR was 10 (normal≤1.1), Prothrombin Time (PT) was 120 (normal<15), Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (APTT) was 148 (normal<40), platelet count was 508 (normal150–400) and C-reactive protein (CRP) was 141 (normal<5). A CT of the head and neck post-tracheostomy showed extensive soft tissue swelling of the neck with compression of the oropharynx and hypopharynx (figures3 4).

caption.title: Lateral radiograph of neck. The arrow points at soft tissue swelling occluding the hypopharynx.
Sagittal section of neck CT. The arrows point at soft tissue compression of the oropharynx and hypopharynx.
Transverse section of neck CT. The arrow points at hypopharyngeal swelling and obstruction.

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: The patient’s warfarin was stopped. He was given 1000 mL of intravenous crystalloid, 500 units of PCC and 10 mg of intravenous vitamin K. He was given intravenous morphine 5 mg and acetaminophen 1 g for pain control.

Following discussion by the multidisciplinary team of anaesthetists, ENT surgeons and the emergency department team, the patient was taken directly to the operating room for an emergency tracheostomy under local anaesthesia.

sec.title: Outcome and follow-up
sec.p: The procedure was well tolerated and the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. The neck swelling subsided over 10 days, and the tracheostomy was removed. He was restarted on oral warfarin 4 mg daily, with an added bridging therapeutic dose of low molecular weight heparin.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Warfarin is a competitive inhibitor of the liver enzyme 2,3-epoxide reductase. It works by interfering with the function of vitamin K-dependent factors X, IX, VII and II and proteins C and S. While warfarin reduces the risk of thromboembolic events, it also increases the risk of bleeding in a log-linear relationship with the INR. The usual causes of supratherapeutic INR are dose non-compliance, drug-drug interactions and comorbidities.6 The cause of supratherapeutic INR in our patient is unknown. His raised alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase suggest impaired liver function. The patient, however, denied alcohol use.

Bleeding complications of warfarin therapy often affect the gastrointestinal and genitourinary systems. However, airway compromise due to lingual and sublingual haematomas in patients with supratherapeutic INR has been reported.79 The involvement of the airway should be suspected in patients who present with dysphagia, drooling, dysphonia and inability to speak. These symptoms indicate an impending airway obstruction requiring immediate and decisive action.

The management of upper airway haematoma or bleeding is centred around meticulous airway assessment and decision on the need for an immediate or pre-emptive definitive airway. This must happen concurrently with the correction of the INR, which includes withholding warfarin and administering vitamin K. In life-threatening bleeding, the addition of 4-factor PCC or FFP is required. Traditionally, 4-factor PCC was given based on the INR and the patient’s weight. However, recently, the American College of Cardiology guideline has recommended a low-dose 4-factor PCC, as it is effective in normalising the INR and also mitigates thrombotic risks.10 Our patient only weighed 51 kg and was given 500 units of 4-factor PCC. In a systematic review of 38 cases of upper airway haematoma from 1950 to 2015, conservative management with vitamin K, FFP or PCC was instituted in 18 (48.6%) patients. Nine patients (24%) had nasal or orotracheal intubation, while tracheotomy was done in 12 (32.43%) patients and two patients had cricothyroidotomy.11 The options for a definitive airway are direct laryngoscopy, video laryngoscopy, fibreoptic-assisted intubation and FONA. The American Society of Anaesthesiologists' (ASA) practice guidelines emphasised the need for preassessment, difficult airway classification, an algorithmic approach and alternative methods for difficult airways.12 The Difficult Airway Society (DAS) guideline 2015 focused on managing an unexpectedly difficult airway. It proposes a stepwise approach from plan A (laryngoscopy) to plan D (can’t intubate and oxygenate), seeking to maximise success at each step.13 However, in upper airway haematoma, surgical airway may be required in up to 40% of cases, suggesting that clinicians must give early consideration to FONA.11 Our patient was unable to lie down in bed; he was tachycardic but oxygenating well. His neck radiograph showed near complete occlusion of the airway at the level of the hypopharynx. These findings preclude supraglottic airway devices and direct or video laryngoscopy. Awake tracheal intubation was considered, but it was felt that bypassing the hypopharyngeal obstruction might be difficult and could precipitate further bleeding. An emergency tracheostomy was preferred as it places the endotracheal tube distal to the pharyngeal obstruction.
The DAS and ASA guidelines emphasised a stepwise approach to difficult airways. However, in upper airway haematoma, it is advisable to proceed directly to a surgical airway.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Existing guidelines emphasise a stepwise approach to difficult airway management. However, in cases of pharyngeal obstruction caused by a haematoma, it is advisable to proceed directly to a surgical airway.

list-item.p: Lingual, sublingual and pharyngeal haematomas can complicate warfarin therapy.

A multidisciplinary team of anaesthetists, the ear, nose and throat specialist and emergency physicians should assess and make a predetermined decision on the best means of securing the airway in patients with airway haematoma.
Surgical airway should be considered early in patients with an upper airway obstruction.

fn.p: Funding: The authors have not declared a specific grant for this research from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

Case reports provide a valuable learning resource for the scientific community and can indicate areas of interest for future research. They should not be used in isolation to guide treatment choices or public health policy.
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient consent for publication: Consent obtained directly from patient(s).
